description: From Late Latin subsumō, equivalent to the Latin sub- (“sub-”) and sūmō (“to take”), cf. the English consume.

verbs.description: subsume (third-person singular simple present subsumes, present participle subsuming, simple past and past participle subsumed)

entries.meaning: To place (any one cognition) under another as belonging to it; to include or contain something else.
examples: A few years later (in a paper published by the Royal Society in 1970, by which time Hawking had become a fellow “for distinction in science” of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge), he and I joined forces to publish an even more powerful theorem which subsumed almost all the work in this area that had gone before.

entries.meaning: To consider an occurrence as part of a principle or rule; to colligate
